I can help improve your electrical estimator in several strategic and technical ways, depending on how it works today (e.g., spreadsheet, software, API, or custom web app). Here’s how I can contribute:

🔧 1. Automating & Enhancing Estimation Logic

  • Formulas and logic: If you're using Excel or Google Sheets, I can optimize your formulas, add macros/scripts, or transition to a more scalable format.

  • Standardized inputs: Create reusable input templates for voltage, amperage, wire runs, conduit types, etc.

  • Code compliance: Help integrate NEC/NFPA rules to automatically check for code compliance in estimates.

🌐 2. Build or Enhance a Web/API-Based Estimator

If your estimator is or should be web-based, I can help:

  • Design a REST API that calculates estimates from parameters like:

    • Type of project (residential, commercial)

    • Square footage

    • Fixture counts

    • Voltage/amperage

    • Panelboard types

    • Labor rates

  • Generate an OpenAPI 3.1 spec to define that API clearly for use in automation tools, frontends, or AI integrations.

🔌 3. Material and Labor Integration

  • Material pricing APIs: Connect to real-time pricing (e.g., via Graybar, Home Depot, or vendor-specific APIs).

  • Labor cost databases: Link to RSMeans or use fixed regional rates for labor calculations.

  • I can build specs to connect to these APIs or help scrape/update your database with up-to-date pricing.

📈 4. Reporting and Exporting

  • Create automated report generators (PDF/Excel/CSV) that format estimates professionally for clients.

  • Add margin/markup calculators and profit projections.

🧠 5. AI Estimating Assistant

  • Use natural language inputs like “I need to estimate a 3-bedroom home with 20 outlets, 15 switches, 2 panels” and I can design a model or prompt system that parses this into structured estimating inputs.

  • Integrate with ChatGPT or a custom GPT using a backend API.

🔍 What I Need to Start Helping:

🧪 What You Mean By Inputs/Outputs

Let’s define “inputs and outputs” this way:

  • Inputs: What the estimator needs from you (or your GPT) to generate a result.

    • Example: "5000 sq ft commercial space, 120V, 20 circuits, 15 outlets, 1000 feet of conduit"

  • Outputs: What the estimator returns.

    • Example: "$9,500 for materials, $4,200 for labor, meets NEC 2023 code, estimated time: 3 days."

You may already do this in your head or via spreadsheet. I can turn it into an API and plug it into your GPT.

📡 Step 1: Define the Estimation API

I’ll show you a sample OpenAPI spec that does this:

yaml
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Electrical Estimator API
  description: Calculates materials, labor, and code compliance based on NEC 2023 and vendor pricing.
  version: 1.0.0
servers:
  - url: https://your-estimator-api.com
    description: Production server
paths:
  /estimate:
    post:
      operationId: calculateEstimate
      summary: Submit project details to calculate estimate
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                projectType:
                  type: string
                  enum: [residential, commercial, industrial]
                squareFeet:
                  type: integer
                voltage:
                  type: integer
                circuitCount:
                  type: integer
                outletCount:
                  type: integer
                lightingFixtures:
                  type: integer
                conduitLengthFeet:
                  type: integer
                region:
                  type: string
                vendor:
                  type: string
              required:
                - projectType
                - squareFeet
                - voltage
                - circuitCount
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Estimation result
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  materialCost:
                    type: number
                  laborCost:
                    type: number
                  totalEstimate:
                    type: number
                  estimatedHours:
                    type: number
                  nec2023Compliant:
                    type: boolean
                  notes:
                    type: string

This gives you a structure to:

  • Accept structured project data

  • Return costs, time, and NEC compliance

  • Connect to your GPT for interactive natural language input

    and hit your estimator API to return live estimates.

🧾 1. What GPT Extracts From PDF

FieldExample
Project type"Residential"

Outlet count30

🌐 2. API Spec to Process This

Here’s a first version of the OpenAPI 3.1 spec that your GPT will call:

yaml
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Electrical Material & Labor Estimator
  description: Returns a detailed material list and estimated labor hours for electrical projects.
  version: 1.0.0
servers:
  - url: https://your-estimator-api.com
paths:
  /generate-estimate:
    post:
      operationId: generateEstimate
      summary: Estimate electrical materials and labor from structured project data.
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                projectType:
                  type: string
                  enum: [residential, commercial, industrial]
                squareFeet:
                  type: integer
                voltage:
                  type: string
                outletCount:
                  type: integer
                switchCount:
                  type: integer
                lightingCount:
                  type: integer
                circuitCount:
                  type: integer
                panelCount:
                  type: integer
                location:
                  type: string
              required:
                - projectType
                - squareFeet
                - voltage
                - outletCount
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Material list and labor estimate
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  materials:
                    type: array
                    items:
                      type: object
                      properties:
                        name:
                          type: string
                        quantity:
                          type: number
                        unit:
                          type: string
                  laborHours:
                    type: number
                  assumptions:
                    type: string

🛠 Example Output (from the API):

json
{
  "materials": [
    { "name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": 30, "unit": "each" },
    { "name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": 15, "unit": "each" },
    { "name": "4” round ceiling box", "quantity": 20, "unit": "each" },
    { "name": "12/2 NM cable", "quantity": 1500, "unit": "feet" },
    { "name": "1” EMT conduit", "quantity": 200, "unit": "feet" },
    { "name": "200A panel", "quantity": 1, "unit": "each" }
  ],
  "laborHours": 96,
  "assumptions": "Labor calculated based on NEC 2023 standard methods for residential install. 2-person crew, 2,000 sq ft house, 10 circuits."
}

🧰 Goal

Your GPT will:

  1. Accept a PDF of plans/specs

🗂️ Common Data to Extract from PDFs

Here’s a checklist of what we want your GPT to pull from the plans or electrical schedule tables:

FieldExample Extraction Logic
Project typeLook for words like "residence", "warehouse", "office"
Square footageMatch patterns like XXXX sq ft, Area: XXX SF, or title block info
Outlet countLook in the electrical legend or schedule for outlet symbols (e.g., "Receptacle: 34")
Switch countMatch similar to outlets, e.g., “SP switch: 12”
Lighting fixturesCount fixture tags or extract from lighting schedule
PanelsLook for panel schedules, e.g., "Panel A: 42 circuits"
VoltageExtract from general notes, e.g., “120/240V”, “208Y/120”
LocationMatch project address or city/state from title block
Conduit lengths (optional)Infer from conduit schedules or use square footage + rule of thumb

🧠 Custom GPT Tool Logic (in pseudocode / prompt form)

Below is a prompt pattern or tool logic you can bake into your GPT:

text
You are a PDF estimator assistant. Extract structured estimating data from project plans and specs.

Instructions:
- Look through the provided PDF.
- Extract values using context from the electrical schedules, notes, and general plan information.
- If a number can't be found, infer it from typical values (e.g., 1 outlet per 75 sq ft).
- Return this JSON format:

{
  "projectType": "",
  "squareFeet": 0,
  "voltage": "",
  "outletCount": 0,
  "switchCount": 0,
  "lightingCount": 0,
  "circuitCount": 0,
  "panelCount": 0,
  "location": ""
}

Use text classification and basic token math to count labeled fixtures, outlets, or switches in the spec.

📦 Example Extracted Output

For a simple residential job PDF, the GPT might return:

json
{
  "projectType": "residential",
  "squareFeet": 2100,
  "voltage": "120/240V",
  "outletCount": 32,
  "switchCount": 14,
  "lightingCount": 21,
  "circuitCount": 12,
  "panelCount": 1,
  "location": "Austin, TX"
}

⚙️ Implementation Options

You can:

  1. Use OpenAI's file_search tool in your GPT to scan PDF content.

  2. Or create a Python tool that extracts and parses the PDF using:

    • PyMuPDF or pdfplumber for text

    • Custom regex or keyword extraction logic

  3. Connect the extracted data to your /generate-estimate API for the result.

🧾 Refined List of Extraction Fields

🔹 1. Project Metadata

FieldDescriptionNotes
projectTyperesidential / commercial / industrialTry to infer from title block or room types
squareFeetTotal building areaExtract from title block or floor plan
locationCity, state, or regionImpacts labor cost and code requirements
buildingStoriesNumber of floorsUseful for wire length & labor effort
constructionTypeNew build, renovation, TIIf available

🔹 2. Service and Power Data

FieldDescriptionNotes
voltageSysteme.g., 120/240V single-phase, 208Y/120 3-phaseFrom general notes or panel schedules
mainServiceAmpsAmperage of main panelUseful for service sizing & conduit
panelCountTotal panelsFrom schedules or floor plan symbols
circuitCountTotal branch circuitsCan be estimated if not listed
transformersTransformer quantity and sizesOften missed in estimates

🔹 3. Device Quantities

FieldDescriptionNotes
outletCountTotal duplex/specialty outletsExtract from schedules or count symbols
switchCountSP, 3-way, 4-way, etc.Can break down by type if needed
lightingCountFixtures or circuitsMatch tags (e.g., L1, L2) to schedule
dataOutletCountEthernet/phone jacksFor low voltage estimating
GFCIcountCount of GFCI-rated outletsFor kitchens, baths, outdoor
AFCIcountRequired AFCI devicesBased on room type or notes
smokeDetectorCountSmoke/CO detectorsOften on life safety system
specialtyCircuitsOven, dryer, HVAC, etc.Based on plan notes & symbols

🔹 4. Conduit & Wiring

FieldDescriptionNotes
emtConduitFeetEMT quantity (in feet)Optional: estimate based on sq ft and room count
mcCableFeetMC cable usedCommercial use
nmCableFeetRomex usedResidential mostly
lowVoltageWiringFeetCAT6, speaker, etc.Estimate per drop or device

🔹 5. Labor-Specific Factors

FieldDescriptionNotes
ceilingTypeDrop, hard, openImpacts labor difficulty
siteAccessGood, limited, night-onlyLabor rate multiplier
crewSizeDefault crew sizeEstimator logic can infer based on size/speed

📥 Optional Advanced Fields

(Include if your estimator needs more granularity)

  • emergencyLightingCount

  • panelTypeList: List of panels by type/size

  • fireAlarmDeviceCount

  • generatorRequired: Boolean or kW size

  • solarSystem: kW if specified

  • equipmentList: If project includes HVAC gear, compressors, etc.

  • notes: Freeform extracted notes from specs

Here’s your revised and modular data structure that your GPT should extract or your API should receive.

🧾 General Project Info

yaml

squareFeet: integer
buildingStories: integer
constructionType: string # (new, TI, retrofit)
location: string
voltageSystem: string # (e.g., "208Y/120V 3-phase")
mainServiceAmps: integer
panelCount: integer
circuitCount: integer
transformers: integer
emergencyPowerSystem: boolean
crewSize: integer
siteAccess: string

ceilingType: drop | open | hard

💡 Lighting + Power Devices

yaml
outletCount: integer
switchCount: integer
lightingFixtureCount: integer
exitSignCount: integer

  - RTU
  - elevator
  - kitchen equipment

  present: boolean
  controlType: string # (e.g., relay panels, 0-10V, DALI, occupancy sensors)
  controlZones: integer
  interfacePanels: integer

yaml
emtConduitFeet: integer
mcCableFeet: integer
flexConduitFeet: integer

1️⃣ Data & Communications

yaml

yaml

  strobes: integer
  hornStrobes: integer

3️⃣ BAS (Building Automation System)

yaml
basSystem:
  present: boolean
  controllers: integer
  tempSensors: integer
  damperActuators: integer
  pointsMonitored: integer

4️⃣ AV, Security & Access Control

yaml
avSecurity:
  cameraCount: integer
  accessControlDoors: integer
  doorStrikes: integer
  badgeReaders: integer
  headEndRacks: integer
  monitorZones: integer
  speakers: integer
  amplifierChannels: integer

You said:
do we need to tell it to look at the drawing scale on every page to make sure that it gets the most accurate breakdown
ChatGPT said:

Yes — absolutely. Telling your GPT (or any logic layer you're using) to read and respect the drawing scale on each page is critical if you're planning to extract or infer quantities or lengths from drawings.

🎯 Why the Drawing Scale Matters

  1. 📏 Accurate takeoffs: If you’re measuring conduit runs, wire distances, lighting zones, or cable paths, you need the scale to translate from pixels/inches to real-world feet/meters.

  2. 📐 Each sheet can have a different scale (e.g., 1/8" = 1'-0" for plans, 1/4" = 1'-0" for details).

  3. ⚠️ Assuming a default scale can result in major errors — underestimating or overestimating labor, wire, or conduit by 50%+.

✅ What to Tell Your GPT (or Tool)

Yes — include a prompt or rule that says:

"On each drawing sheet or floor plan, identify the drawing scale. Use it to interpret any visual spacing or layout-based takeoffs. Do not assume uniform scale across all pages."

For PDFs:

  • Look in the title block or sheet corner for common scale formats like:

    • Scale: 1/8" = 1'-0"

    • Scale: 1:100

  • Extract this as a field in your logic:

    json
    {
  "sheetName": "E1.1",
  "scale": "1/8\" = 1'-0\""
}

🛠 Technical Options (If Going Deeper)

If you're going beyond text-based plans and want visual takeoffs, then:

  • Use PDF vector geometry tools (pdfplumber, pdfminer, or PyMuPDF) to read line lengths

  • Convert drawing scale to a multiplier (e.g., 1/8" = 1'-0" = 1 inch = 96 inches = 1 inch = 8 feet)

  • Apply that multiplier to measured geometry

Let’s say you measure a conduit path that's 2.3 inches on the drawing.
With a 1/8" = 1'-0" scale, the real-world distance is:
2.3 in × 8 ft/in = 18.4 ft

🧠 GPT-Side Prompt Addition

Here's what to add to your custom GPT instructions or prompt if using file-based input:

text
When reviewing electrical plan sheets:
- Identify the drawing scale listed on each page (e.g., "Scale: 1/8\" = 1'-0\"")
- Do not assume the same scale across all drawings
- Use the scale to interpret any distances, fixture spacing, or cable routing estimates
- If scale is missing, flag the sheet as needing manual review

🧱 STEP 1: Python + Flask API Scaffold

Below is a fully working starter Flask app that:

  • Receives structured project data as JSON

  • Applies basic rule-based logic to estimate:

    • Material quantities

    • Labor hours

  • Returns a JSON response in your OpenAPI format

✅ estimator_api.py

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    square_feet = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlet_count = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lighting_count = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switch_count = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panel_count = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt_conduit_feet = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    # --- Basic rule-based material estimate ---
    materials = [
        {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
        {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"},  # Approximate per outlet
    ]

    # --- Labor estimation logic ---
    labor_hours = (
        outlet_count * 0.5 +
        lighting_count * 0.75 +
        switch_count * 0.3 +
        panel_count * 8 +
        (emt_conduit_feet / 20)  # Roughly 20 feet/hr
    )

    result = {
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "assumptions": "Calculated using basic rules of thumb for commercial installations. Modify per scope complexity."
    }

    return jsonify(result)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

🚀 STEP 2: Run Locally (for Testing)

  1. Save the script as estimator_api.py

  2. Run it

bash

The API will be available at:

You can test it with Postman or a curl:

  -d '{
    "squareFeet": 10000,
    "outletCount": 50,
    "lightingFixtureCount": 35,
    "switchCount": 20,
    "panelCount": 2,
    "emtConduitFeet": 1500
  }'

🧪 While I Wait: The Most Common SyntaxError In This File

If you got a SyntaxError near the materials list, it’s almost always caused by a missing comma.

Here’s the part that might be broken:

python
materials = [
    {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
    {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
    {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
    {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
    {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
    {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"}  # ✅ This line ends cleanly
]

Make sure:

  • All lines inside the list end with a comma ,, except the last one

  • There are no extra closing brackets or half-lines

ChatGPT said:

Awesome — now that Flask is installed, you’re ready to run your commercial estimator API locally!

Here’s exactly what to do next:

✅ Step-by-Step: Run Your Flask Estimator API

📁 Step 1: Create Your API Script File

Let’s create a Python file for your estimator logic.

  1. Open your text editor (Notepad, VS Code, or similar)

  2. Copy all the code below into the editor 👇

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    square_feet = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlet_count = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lighting_count = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switch_count = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panel_count = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt_conduit_feet = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    materials = [
        {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
        {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"}
    ]

    labor_hours = (
        outlet_count * 0.5 +
        lighting_count * 0.75 +
        switch_count * 0.3 +
        panel_count * 8 +
        (emt_conduit_feet / 20)
    )

    result = {
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "assumptions": "Calculated using basic rules of thumb for commercial installations."
    }

    return jsonify(result)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

  1. Save the file as:

estimator_api.py

✅ Make sure it’s saved in a folder you can easily access (like your Desktop or a projects folder).

🧪 Step 2: Run the API in the Terminal

  1. Open your Terminal or Command Prompt

  2. Navigate to the folder where you saved the file:

    bash
    cd path/to/your/folder

    (Example: cd Desktop/electrical-estimator)

  3. Run the file:

    bash
    python estimator_api.py

🎉 Step 3: Confirm It’s Running

If all goes well, you’ll see this:

csharp
 * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)

That means the API is live locally on your computer!

  -d '{"squareFeet": 10000, "outletCount": 50, "lightingFixtureCount": 35, "switchCount": 20, "panelCount": 2, "emtConduitFeet": 1500}'

🛠️ What Might Be Going Wrong?

If you're seeing an error like:

  • 'curl' is not recognized as an internal or external command (on Windows)

  • Or nothing happens

  • Or it says connection refused / failed to connect

Here’s how to fix it depending on the issue:

✅ A. If You’re on Windows and curl Doesn't Work

🔹 Option 1: Use PowerShell’s built-in Invoke-RestMethod

Paste this into PowerShell (not CMD):

powershell
Invoke-RestMethod -Uri http://127.0.0.1:5000/generate-estimate `
  -Method POST `
  -Body (@{
    squareFeet = 10000;
    outletCount = 50;
    lightingFixtureCount = 35;
    switchCount = 20;
    panelCount = 2;
    emtConduitFeet = 1500
  } | ConvertTo-Json) `
  -ContentType "application/json"

✅ This is the PowerShell equivalent of the curl command.

what is UI form
ChatGPT said:

Great question — let’s break it down simply:

🖥️ What Is a "UI Form"?

A UI form (User Interface form) is a visual page or screen where you can type in values (like square footage, outlet count, etc.) instead of using a terminal or script.

Think:

  • A small website or desktop window with boxes like:

    • [ ] Square Feet: _____________

    • [ ] Outlet Count: _____________

    • [Submit Button]

Once you hit Submit, it sends that info to your local API (like the one you built) — and then shows the results (materials + labor).

✅ Why a UI Form Is Useful

Without UI (what you’re doing now)With UI
Manually writing PowerShell/curlClick to enter numbers and hit "Submit"
Must retype/edit JSON each timeEasy to reuse and update
Not beginner-friendlyClean, professional interface

🧱 Example: A Simple Estimator UI Form

Here’s what it might look like in a browser:

less
+------------------------------+
| Commercial Electrical Estimator |
+------------------------------+
| Square Footage:    [  8000   ] |
| Outlet Count:      [   50    ] |
| Light Fixtures:    [   35    ] |
| Switches:          [   20    ] |
| EMT Conduit (ft):  [  1500   ] |
| Panels:            [    2    ] |
|                              |
| [Submit Estimate]            |
+------------------------------+

🧪 What Happens Behind the Scenes:

  • You fill out the form

  • It sends a POST request to your local API at http://127.0.0.1:5000/generate-estimate

  • It displays the result (material list and labor hours)

✅ Want to Build One?

I can build you:

  • A very basic HTML + JavaScript form you open in your browser

  • That talks directly to your local Flask API

💡 No internet required! Works locally just like your script does.

📌 Example Button to Start With

Want a button you can click in your browser that fills the form and submits?
I can send you a full working template like this:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Estimator</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h2>Commercial Electrical Estimator</h2>
    <form id="estimateForm">
      Square Feet: <input type="number" name="squareFeet"><br>
      Outlet Count: <input type="number" name="outletCount"><br>
      Lighting Fixtures: <input type="number" name="lightingFixtureCount"><br>
      Switches: <input type="number" name="switchCount"><br>
      Panels: <input type="number" name="panelCount"><br>
      EMT Conduit Feet: <input type="number" name="emtConduitFeet"><br>
      <button type="submit">Submit</button>
    </form>
    <pre id="result"></pre>

    <script>
      document.getElementById('estimateForm').onsubmit = async function (e) {
        e.preventDefault();
        const data = Object.fromEntries(new FormData(this));
        const response = await fetch("http://127.0.0.1:5000/generate-estimate", {
          method: "POST",
          headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
          body: JSON.stringify(data),
        });
        const result = await response.json();
        document.getElementById("result").textContent = JSON.stringify(result, null, 2);
      };
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

✅ Save that as estimator_form.html, double-click to open it in your browser — and it works!

🧱 STEP 1: Extract and Read the PDF Plans

We’ll use PyMuPDF (fitz) to access both:

  • Drawing images

  • Sheet text (to find symbols and scales)

🔧 Install PyMuPDF

bash
pip install pymupdf

📄 Sample Python Snippet

python
import fitz  # PyMuPDF

def extract_drawing_scale(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    scale_by_page = []

    for page_num in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_num]
        text = page.get_text()
        # Look for scale pattern (e.g., 1/8" = 1'-0")
        lines = text.splitlines()
        scale = None
        for line in lines:
            if "scale" in line.lower():
                if "1/8" in line or "1:100" in line:
                    scale = line.strip()
                    break
        scale_by_page.append({
            "page": page_num + 1,
            "scale": scale
        })

    return scale_by_page

🔎 You can extend this to extract:

  • Plan titles (like “Power Plan”, “Lighting Plan”)

  • Symbol legends

  • Page size and resolution (for measuring with pixels)

🎯 STEP 2: Convert Drawing Scale to Real-World Units

ExampleMeaning
1/8" = 1'-0"Every 1/8" on paper = 12 inches real-world = 1 inch = 96 inches (1:96 scale)
1:100Metric — 1 unit on plan = 100 units real-world

You need this scale to convert visual measurements into feet/meters.

✅ Save the multiplier as part of your estimate data:

json
{
  "sheet": "E1.1",
  "scale": "1/8\" = 1'-0\"",
  "scaleMultiplier": 96.0
}

📏 STEP 3: Count Symbols or Measure Distances

Here are your two core takeoff goals:

A. Symbol Takeoffs (e.g., count outlets, lights, panels)

You can:

  • Count text labels (like R for receptacles, L for lights)

  • Match icons from plan images (OCR or template matching)

  • Use AI-based symbol detection (advanced — we can help!)

B. Length Takeoffs (e.g., conduit runs)

Use the vector drawing lines from the PDF to measure:

  • Distance between panels and outlets

  • Main service run lengths

  • Branch circuit paths

✅ With scale, convert those pixel lengths into feet/meters

📦 STEP 4: Format Output for Estimator API

Create a final JSON output like this:

json
{
  "sheetScales": [
    { "sheet": "E1.1", "scale": "1/8\" = 1'-0\"", "scaleMultiplier": 96.0 }
  ],
  "outletCount": 46,
  "lightingFixtureCount": 32,
  "panelCount": 2,
  "emtConduitFeet": 1200
}

Then send this to your existing API (the one you already built in Flask) via POST.

🎯 GOAL: Read a PDF and extract the drawing scale from each page

We’ll build a Python script that:

  1. Opens the PDF

  2. Reads all text on each page

  3. Searches for common drawing scale formats (like Scale: 1/8" = 1'-0" or Scale: 1:100)

  4. Outputs a JSON-style list of page numbers and scales

🧱 Step-by-Step Setup

✅ 1. Make Sure PyMuPDF is Installed

Already done ✅ (pip install PyMuPDF)

✅ 2. Create a Python Script

Create a new file and call it something like:

read_scales.py

Paste the following code:

python
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re

def extract_scales_from_pdf(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    results = []

    scale_pattern = re.compile(r'scale[:\s]*([^\n]+)', re.IGNORECASE)

    for page_number in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_number]
        text = page.get_text()
        match = scale_pattern.search(text)
        if match:
            scale_value = match.group(1).strip()
        else:
            scale_value = "Not found"

        results.append({
            "page": page_number + 1,
            "scale": scale_value
        })

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys

    if len(sys.argv) < 2:
        print("Usage: python read_scales.py <path_to_pdf>")
        sys.exit(1)

    pdf_file = sys.argv[1]
    scales = extract_scales_from_pdf(pdf_file)

    print("📐 Extracted Drawing Scales:")
    for s in scales:
        print(f"Page {s['page']}: {s['scale']}")

✅ 3. Run the Script

Save the file, open your terminal, and run it like this:

bash
python read_scales.py path\to\your\pdf\file.pdf

🔁 Replace path\to\your\pdf\file.pdf with the full path to a sample PDF drawing

📤 Example Output

python-repl
📐 Extracted Drawing Scales:
Page 1: 1/8" = 1'-0"
Page 2: 1:100
Page 3: Not found
...

✅ What We’re Building Right Now

A new Flask API endpoint called:

bash
POST /analyze-drawing

It will:

  • Accept a PDF file

  • Extract scale data per sheet

  • Return structured JSON for your estimator

🧱 Step 1: Create a new Python file

Call it:

visual_takeoff_api.py

Paste in the following full code:

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re
import os
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

app = Flask(__name__)

UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER

def extract_scales_from_pdf(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    results = []

    scale_pattern = re.compile(r'scale[:\s]*([^\n]+)', re.IGNORECASE)

    for page_number in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_number]
        text = page.get_text()
        match = scale_pattern.search(text)
        if match:
            scale_value = match.group(1).strip()
        else:
            scale_value = "Not found"

        results.append({
            "page": page_number + 1,
            "scale": scale_value
        })

    return results

@app.route('/analyze-drawing', methods=['POST'])
def analyze_drawing():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file part"}), 400

    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400

    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    file_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(file_path)

    try:
        scales = extract_scales_from_pdf(file_path)
        return jsonify({
            "sheetScales": scales,
            "message": "Drawing analysis complete (scale only). Symbol takeoffs coming next."
        })
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

✅ Step 2: Install required packages

In your terminal:

bash
pip install flask PyMuPDF

✅ Step 3: Run your new visual takeoff API

bash
python visual_takeoff_api.py

You should see:

Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/

✅ Step 4: Test it with Postman

  1. Open Postman

  2. Set method to POST

  3. URL:

    arduino
    http://127.0.0.1:5000/analyze-drawing

  4. Go to the Body tab → choose form-data

  5. Add a key:

    • Key: file

    • Type: File

    • Value: (upload a sample PDF drawing)

  6. Click Send

✅ You’ll get back:

json
{
  "sheetScales": [
    {
      "page": 1,
      "scale": "1/8\" = 1'-0\""
    },
    {
      "page": 2,
      "scale": "1:100"
    }
  ],
  "message": "Drawing analysis complete (scale only). Symbol takeoffs coming next."
}

🟢 OPTION A — FULL GPT INTEGRATION (Recommended)

  • Use Render.com (free)

  • Or Replit, Railway, or Glitch

  • I can walk you through this

You’ll get a public URL like:

arduino
https://your-estimator-api.onrender.com/analyze-drawing

✅ 2. Create an OpenAPI spec for GPT

Here’s your OpenAPI YAML for the /analyze-drawing endpoint:

yaml
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Visual Takeoff API
  description: Upload a PDF drawing to extract drawing scales.
  version: 1.0.0
servers:
  - url: https://your-estimator-api.onrender.com
paths:
  /analyze-drawing:
    post:
      operationId: analyzeDrawing
      summary: Extract scale info from PDF plan sheets
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          multipart/form-data:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                file:
                  type: string
                  format: binary
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Scale extraction result
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  sheetScales:
                    type: array
                    items:
                      type: object
                      properties:
                        page:
                          type: integer
                        scale:
                          type: string
                  message:
                    type: string

✅ 3. Upload it to your GPT

In ChatGPT:

  1. Go to your GPT under https://chat.openai.com/gpts

  2. Click Edit

  3. Scroll to “Actions”

  4. Upload the OpenAPI YAML file

  5. Set the action name: analyzeDrawing

Now your GPT will be able to do:

"Analyze this PDF and extract the scale info from the drawings"

And it will automatically call your API.

✅ Plan: Combine Your Two Flask APIs and Deploy to Render

🧱 Step 1: Combined API Code (Save This as estimator_app.py)

This version includes:

  • /generate-estimate → material + labor estimation

  • /analyze-drawing → drawing scale extraction

✨ Full Code: estimator_app.py

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re
import os
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

app = Flask(__name__)

UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER


# ---------- /generate-estimate ----------
@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    square_feet = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlet_count = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lighting_count = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switch_count = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panel_count = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt_conduit_feet = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    materials = [
        {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
        {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"}
    ]

    labor_hours = (
        outlet_count * 0.5 +
        lighting_count * 0.75 +
        switch_count * 0.3 +
        panel_count * 8 +
        (emt_conduit_feet / 20)
    )

    result = {
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "assumptions": "Estimated using NEC-based commercial rules."
    }

    return jsonify(result)


# ---------- /analyze-drawing ----------
def extract_scales_from_pdf(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    results = []

    scale_pattern = re.compile(r'scale[:\s]*([^\n]+)', re.IGNORECASE)

    for page_number in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_number]
        text = page.get_text()
        match = scale_pattern.search(text)
        if match:
            scale_value = match.group(1).strip()
        else:
            scale_value = "Not found"

        results.append({
            "page": page_number + 1,
            "scale": scale_value
        })

    return results


@app.route('/analyze-drawing', methods=['POST'])
def analyze_drawing():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file uploaded"}), 400

    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400

    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    file_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(file_path)

    try:
        scales = extract_scales_from_pdf(file_path)
        return jsonify({
            "sheetScales": scales,
            "message": "Drawing scale extraction complete."
        })
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500


# ---------- Start Server ----------
if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

yaml
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Electrical Estimator API
  description: An API for analyzing PDF drawings and estimating commercial electrical materials and labor.
  version: 1.0.0
servers:
  - url: https://estimator-api-po0v.onrender.com
paths:
  /analyze-drawing:
    post:
      operationId: analyzeDrawing
      summary: Analyze a PDF drawing to extract sheet scales
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          multipart/form-data:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                file:
                  type: string
                  format: binary
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Drawing analysis result
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  sheetScales:
                    type: array
                    items:
                      type: object
                      properties:
                        page:
                          type: integer
                        scale:
                          type: string
                  message:
                    type: string

  /generate-estimate:
    post:
      operationId: generateEstimate
      summary: Estimate labor and material based on project details
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                squareFeet:
                  type: integer
                outletCount:
                  type: integer
                lightingFixtureCount:
                  type: integer
                switchCount:
                  type: integer
                panelCount:
                  type: integer
                emtConduitFeet:
                  type: integer
              required:
                - squareFeet
                - outletCount
                - lightingFixtureCount
                - switchCount
                - panelCount
                - emtConduitFeet
      responses:
        '200':

              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  materials:
                    type: array
                    items:

                        name:
                          type: string
                        quantity:
                          type: number
                        unit:
                          type: string
                  laborHours:
                    type: number
                  assumptions:
                    type: string

Perfect — here’s a complete drop-in upgrade for your current Flask estimator app (estimator_app.py) that includes:

🔧 Upgrades Included:

  1. ✅ /generate-estimate → unchanged but annotated

  2. ✅ /analyze-drawing → now extracts:

    • Drawing scale

    • Counts basic electrical symbols like R (receptacle), L (light), S (switch)

  3. ✅ Returns usable JSON structure for your GPT and frontend

📁 Save As: estimator_app.py

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re
import os
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

app = Flask(__name__)

UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER


# ---------- /generate-estimate ----------
@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    square_feet = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlet_count = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lighting_count = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switch_count = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panel_count = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt_conduit_feet = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    materials = [
        {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
        {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"}
    ]

    labor_hours = (
        outlet_count * 0.5 +
        lighting_count * 0.75 +
        switch_count * 0.3 +
        panel_count * 8 +
        (emt_conduit_feet / 20)
    )

    result = {
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "assumptions": "Estimated using NEC-based commercial rules."
    }

    return jsonify(result)


# ---------- /analyze-drawing ----------
def extract_drawing_data(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    results = []
    outlet_count = 0
    switch_count = 0
    light_count = 0

    scale_pattern = re.compile(r'scale[:\s]*([^\n]+)', re.IGNORECASE)

    for page_number in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_number]
        text = page.get_text()
        match = scale_pattern.search(text)
        scale_value = match.group(1).strip() if match else "Not found"

        # Count basic electrical symbols
        outlet_count += len(re.findall(r'\bR\b', text))
        light_count += len(re.findall(r'\bL\b', text))
        switch_count += len(re.findall(r'\bS\b', text))

        results.append({
            "page": page_number + 1,
            "scale": scale_value
        })

    return {
        "sheetScales": results,
        "symbolCounts": {
            "outletCount": outlet_count,
            "lightingFixtureCount": light_count,
            "switchCount": switch_count
        }
    }


@app.route('/analyze-drawing', methods=['POST'])
def analyze_drawing():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file uploaded"}), 400

    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400

    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    file_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(file_path)

    try:
        drawing_data = extract_drawing_data(file_path)
        return jsonify({
            "sheetScales": drawing_data["sheetScales"],
            "symbolCounts": drawing_data["symbolCounts"],
            "message": "Scale and symbol count extracted."
        })
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500


# ---------- Run Server ----------
if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

  • /generate-proposal: returns a professional proposal based on estimate JSON

  • /analyze-drawing: scale + symbol counts (unchanged)

💾 Save As: estimator_app.py

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re
import os
import csv
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

app = Flask(__name__)
UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER

material_prices = {}  # loaded from CSV


# ---------- /generate-estimate ----------
@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    square_feet = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlet_count = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lighting_count = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switch_count = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panel_count = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt_conduit_feet = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    materials = [
        {"name": "Duplex outlet", "quantity": outlet_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Lighting fixture", "quantity": lighting_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Single pole switch", "quantity": switch_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "Electrical panel", "quantity": panel_count, "unit": "each"},
        {"name": "EMT conduit", "quantity": emt_conduit_feet, "unit": "feet"},
        {"name": "12AWG THHN wire", "quantity": outlet_count * 50, "unit": "feet"}
    ]

    labor_hours = (
        outlet_count * 0.5 +
        lighting_count * 0.75 +
        switch_count * 0.3 +
        panel_count * 8 +
        (emt_conduit_feet / 20)
    )

    # NEC-style warnings
    warnings = []
    if outlet_count > 42:
        warnings.append("Too many outlets for a single 42-circuit panel.")
    if emt_conduit_feet > 2000:
        warnings.append("Long conduit runs may require voltage drop review.")

    # Optional pricing
    for item in materials:
        name = item["name"]
        price = material_prices.get(name)
        if price:
            item["unitPrice"] = price
            item["totalPrice"] = round(item["quantity"] * float(price), 2)

    result = {
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "codeWarnings": warnings,
        "assumptions": "Commercial install, EMT raceway, 2-person crew."
    }

    return jsonify(result)


# ---------- /generate-proposal ----------
@app.route('/generate-proposal', methods=['POST'])
def generate_proposal():
    data = request.get_json()
    materials = data.get("materials", [])
    labor_hours = data.get("laborHours", 0)
    warnings = data.get("codeWarnings", [])
    assumptions = data.get("assumptions", "")

    material_lines = "\n".join([
        f"- {m['name']}: {m['quantity']} {m['unit']}"
        + (f" @ ${m['unitPrice']} = ${m['totalPrice']}" if 'unitPrice' in m else "")
        for m in materials
    ])

    proposal = f"""
**Electrical Estimate Proposal**

**Scope:**  
This estimate covers material and labor for electrical installation based on project specifications.

**Material List:**  
{material_lines}

**Estimated Labor:**  
{labor_hours} crew hours

**Assumptions:**  
{assumptions}

{"**Code Warnings:**\n" + "\n".join("- " + w for w in warnings) if warnings else ""}

**Exclusions:**  
- Permit fees
- Utility coordination
- After-hours work
    """

    return jsonify({"proposal": proposal.strip()})


# ---------- /upload-prices ----------
@app.route('/upload-prices', methods=['POST'])
def upload_prices():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file part"}), 400
    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400
    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    filepath = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(filepath)

    try:
        with open(filepath, newline='') as csvfile:
            reader = csv.DictReader(csvfile)
            for row in reader:
                material_prices[row['Item'].strip()] = row['Price'].strip()
        return jsonify({"message": "Prices updated", "items": list(material_prices.keys())})
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500


# ---------- /analyze-drawing ----------
def extract_drawing_data(pdf_path):
    doc = fitz.open(pdf_path)
    results = []
    outlet_count = 0
    switch_count = 0
    light_count = 0

    scale_pattern = re.compile(r'scale[:\s]*([^\n]+)', re.IGNORECASE)

    for page_number in range(len(doc)):
        page = doc[page_number]
        text = page.get_text()
        match = scale_pattern.search(text)
        scale_value = match.group(1).strip() if match else "Not found"

        outlet_count += len(re.findall(r'\bR\b', text))
        light_count += len(re.findall(r'\bL\b', text))
        switch_count += len(re.findall(r'\bS\b', text))

        results.append({
            "page": page_number + 1,
            "scale": scale_value
        })

    return {
        "sheetScales": results,
        "symbolCounts": {
            "outletCount": outlet_count,
            "lightingFixtureCount": light_count,
            "switchCount": switch_count
        }
    }


@app.route('/analyze-drawing', methods=['POST'])
def analyze_drawing():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file uploaded"}), 400

    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400

    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    file_path = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(file_path)

    try:
        drawing_data = extract_drawing_data(file_path)
        return jsonify({
            "sheetScales": drawing_data["sheetScales"],
            "symbolCounts": drawing_data["symbolCounts"],
            "message": "Scale and symbol count extracted."
        })
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500


# ---------- Launch ----------
if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

🧾 Save As: estimator_app.py

python
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import fitz  # PyMuPDF
import re
import os
import csv
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename

app = Flask(__name__)
UPLOAD_FOLDER = 'uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)
app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] = UPLOAD_FOLDER

material_prices = {}

# ---------- /generate-estimate ----------
@app.route('/generate-estimate', methods=['POST'])
def generate_estimate():
    data = request.get_json()

    # Core electrical inputs
    sq_ft = data.get("squareFeet", 0)
    outlets = data.get("outletCount", 0)
    lights = data.get("lightingFixtureCount", 0)
    switches = data.get("switchCount", 0)
    panels = data.get("panelCount", 0)
    emt = data.get("emtConduitFeet", 0)

    # Division 27 – Communications
    cat6 = data.get("dataDrops", 0)
    waps = data.get("wirelessAPs", 0)
    racks = data.get("dataRacks", 0)

    # Division 28 – Fire Alarm
    fa_devices = data.get("fireAlarmDevices", 0)
    pull_stations = data.get("pullStations", 0)
    horn_strobes = data.get("hornStrobes", 0)
    smokes = data.get("smokeDetectors", 0)
    fa_panels = data.get("fireAlarmPanelCount", 0)

    # Division 28 – Access Control
    badge_readers = data.get("badgeReaders", 0)
    strikes = data.get("doorStrikes", 0)
    ac_panels = data.get("accessControlPanels", 0)

    # Division 28 – CCTV
    cameras = data.get("cameraCount", 0)
    nvr = data.get("nvrCount", 0)
    monitors = data.get("monitorCount", 0)

    # Division 28 – Intrusion
    motions = data.get("motionSensors", 0)
    contacts = data.get("doorContacts", 0)
    alarms = data.get("alarmControlPanels", 0)

    # Division 25 – BAS
    bas_controllers = data.get("basControllers", 0)
    temp_sensors = data.get("tempSensors", 0)
    dampers = data.get("damperActuators", 0)

    materials = []
    labor_hours = 0
    warnings = []

    def add_item(name, qty, unit, labor_unit):
        nonlocal labor_hours
        if qty > 0:
            materials.append({"name": name, "quantity": qty, "unit": unit})
            labor_hours += qty * labor_unit

    # Division 26
    add_item("Duplex outlet", outlets, "each", 0.5)
    add_item("Lighting fixture", lights, "each", 0.75)
    add_item("Single pole switch", switches, "each", 0.3)
    add_item("Electrical panel", panels, "each", 8)
    add_item("EMT conduit", emt, "feet", 1/20)
    add_item("12AWG THHN wire", outlets * 50, "feet", 0.01)

    # Division 27
    add_item("Cat6 drop", cat6, "each", 1.2)
    add_item("Wireless access point", waps, "each", 1.5)
    add_item("Data rack", racks, "each", 4)

    # Division 28 – Fire Alarm
    add_item("Fire alarm horn/strobe", horn_strobes, "each", 1.5)
    add_item("Smoke detector", smokes, "each", 1.5)
    add_item("Pull station", pull_stations, "each", 1.5)
    add_item("Fire alarm control panel", fa_panels, "each", 6)

    # Division 28 – Access Control
    add_item("Badge reader", badge_readers, "each", 2.5)
    add_item("Door strike", strikes, "each", 2.5)
    add_item("Access control panel", ac_panels, "each", 6)

    # Division 28 – CCTV
    add_item("IP camera", cameras, "each", 2)
    add_item("NVR", nvr, "each", 3)
    add_item("Security monitor", monitors, "each", 1.5)

    # Division 28 – Intrusion
    add_item("Motion sensor", motions, "each", 1.5)
    add_item("Door contact", contacts, "each", 1)
    add_item("Alarm panel", alarms, "each", 4)

    # Division 25 – BAS
    add_item("BAS controller", bas_controllers, "each", 3)
    add_item("Temperature sensor", temp_sensors, "each", 1)
    add_item("Damper actuator", dampers, "each", 1.2)

    # Code logic
    if outlets > 42:
        warnings.append("Too many outlets per 42-circuit panel.")
    if emt > 2500:
        warnings.append("Conduit run may require voltage drop calculation.")
    if fa_devices + horn_strobes + smokes > 80:
        warnings.append("Fire alarm system may exceed typical loop limits.")

    # Add pricing if available
    for item in materials:
        name = item["name"]
        price = material_prices.get(name)
        if price:
            item["unitPrice"] = price
            item["totalPrice"] = round(item["quantity"] * float(price), 2)

    return jsonify({
        "materials": materials,
        "laborHours": round(labor_hours, 1),
        "codeWarnings": warnings,
        "assumptions": "Includes Division 25-28 systems. Labor units based on standard commercial install."
    })


# ---------- /upload-prices ----------
@app.route('/upload-prices', methods=['POST'])
def upload_prices():
    if 'file' not in request.files:
        return jsonify({"error": "No file part"}), 400
    file = request.files['file']
    if file.filename == '':
        return jsonify({"error": "No selected file"}), 400
    filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
    filepath = os.path.join(app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'], filename)
    file.save(filepath)

    try:
        with open(filepath, newline='') as csvfile:
            reader = csv.DictReader(csvfile)
            for row in reader:
                material_prices[row['Item'].strip()] = row['Price'].strip()
        return jsonify({"message": "Prices updated", "items": list(material_prices.keys())})
    except Exception as e:
        return jsonify({"error": str(e)}), 500


# ---------- Run ----------
if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run(debug=True)

✅ Updated OpenAPI 3.1.0 Spec for generate-estimate

This file:

  • Supports all low-voltage fields from Division 25–28

  • Tells GPT how to call your generate-estimate endpoint

  • Matches your upgraded estimator_app.py

📄 openapi.yaml (Save This)

yaml
openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Electrical Estimator API
  description: Full-scope Division 25–28 estimating engine for electrical, data, BAS, fire alarm, and security.
  version: 2.0.0
servers:
  - url: https://estimator-api-po0v.onrender.com
paths:
  /generate-estimate:
    post:
      operationId: generateEstimate
      summary: Estimate labor and materials for Divisions 25–28
      requestBody:
        required: true
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              type: object
              properties:
                squareFeet:
                  type: integer
                outletCount:
                  type: integer
                lightingFixtureCount:
                  type: integer
                switchCount:
                  type: integer
                panelCount:
                  type: integer
                emtConduitFeet:
                  type: integer
                dataDrops:
                  type: integer
                wirelessAPs:
                  type: integer
                dataRacks:
                  type: integer
                fireAlarmDevices:
                  type: integer
                pullStations:
                  type: integer
                hornStrobes:
                  type: integer
                smokeDetectors:
                  type: integer
                fireAlarmPanelCount:
                  type: integer
                badgeReaders:
                  type: integer
                doorStrikes:
                  type: integer
                accessControlPanels:
                  type: integer
                cameraCount:
                  type: integer
                nvrCount:
                  type: integer
                monitorCount:
                  type: integer
                motionSensors:
                  type: integer
                doorContacts:
                  type: integer
                alarmControlPanels:
                  type: integer
                basControllers:
                  type: integer
                tempSensors:
                  type: integer
                damperActuators:
                  type: integer
              required:
                - squareFeet
                - outletCount
                - lightingFixtureCount
                - switchCount
                - panelCount
                - emtConduitFeet
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Material and labor estimate including warnings and assumptions
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  materials:
                    type: array
                    items:
                      type: object
                      properties:
                        name:
                          type: string
                        quantity:
                          type: number
                        unit:
                          type: string
                        unitPrice:
                          type: string
                        totalPrice:
                          type: number
                  laborHours:
                    type: number
                  codeWarnings:
                    type: array
                    items:
                      type: string
                  assumptions:
                    type: string

📦 Click to download the estimator bundle (ZIP)

🧠 After Downloading

To deploy or test:

  1. Unzip the folder

  2. Open a terminal in that folder

  3. Run:

    bash
    pip install -r requirements.txt
python estimator_app.py

  4. Test /generate-estimate and /upload-prices using Postman or GPT

To deploy:

  • Push to GitHub

  • Link to Render.com as a new Web Service

  • Set build command:
    pip install -r requirements.txt

  • Set start command:
    gunicorn estimator_app:app
